body.p: However, the IASB noted that such an approach would not be consistent with the approach in IAS 39 because:

li.p: the accounting treatment in accordance with IAS 39 is dependent on, and reflects, the purpose (ie whether it is for ‘own use’) for which the contracts to buy or sell non-financial items are entered into and continue to be held for. This is different from a free choice, which would allow, but not require, the accounting treatment to reflect the purpose of the contract.

in accordance with IAS 39, if similar contracts have been settled net, a contract to buy or sell non-financial items that can be settled net in cash must be accounted for as a derivative. Hence, a free choice would allow an entity to account for a commodity contract as a derivative regardless of whether similar contracts have been settled net in cash.

body.p: Consequently, in the Exposure Draft Hedge Accounting (the ‘2010 Hedge Accounting Exposure Draft’), the IASB decided not to propose that entities can elect to account for commodity contracts as derivatives.
